item.title: G1 Chango Lo Che
item.description:
Name: Chango Lo Che
Player size: 5-10
Age: 5-13
Sex: Both
Duration: 10-20
Occasion: exercise
Category: ball, exercise
Traditional: somewhat
Material needed: ball
Mechanics: player elimination, real time


Name explanation: Chango Lo Che means "new pass". This is not a Maa name but that is the name they children use.
History: It's not a traditional game but it has been around for at least 40 years. The kids learn it mostly at school
Usage: Played often in the school yard in Mile 46
Information retrieval:
Ezekiel Roimen interviewed Senewa Maison on the 10-11-2024 and this is her favourite game
Ezekiel Roimen remembers this game from his school time


started by two players standing in opposite side and the other players at the middle of the field
the two outside players throw the ball onto the players in the middle after each other and try to hit them
the players in the middle therefore run each time to the opposite side of the throwing outside player
if someone is hit he or she is out of the game
if only one person remains in the middle, the two outside players will try for 5 more times (they often count down loudly), if the middle person survives this her or she is the winner

Two outside player, which try to hit the middle players with a ball

item.title: G2 Osurruo
item.description:
Name: Osurruo
Player size: 2-4
Age: 6-15
Sex: Both
Duration: 10-30
Occasion: leisure
Category: mental, dexterity
Traditional: yes
Material needed: stones (1 main stone for each player and 12 additional stones)
Mechanics: pattern building, real time, dexterity


Name explanation: no particular meaning, but the main stone of each player is called "Olmenye" which means father in Maa
History: Old game that is played by Masaai for at least several generations
Usage: It is still very liked among kids and often played in school breaks. It is also liked for leisure occasions as it does not require much movement.
Information retrieval:
Ezekiel Roimen interviewed Senewa Maison on the 10-11-2024


Each player has one main stone called "Olmenye" (father in Maa) this has to be thrown and catched as the player removes or returns the other 12 stones (called cows) into a hole
The players rotate usually clockwise. One player starts and the others watch if he or she plays right. What matters is that the playing player returns the stones in the right manner.
At the start the main stone is thrown in the air and all other 12 stones have to be removed out of the hole before the Olmenye is catched again.
Afterwards 1 stone has to be returned for each time the Olmenye is thrown into the air. Only the same hand can be used for all this!
Then all stones are removed again (with the same hand during another throw of the Olmenye) and the player has to return 2 each at once until finishing all 12.
This is then continued with returning 3 each, then 4 each, until all 12 are returned at once. If a round number is not dividing 12 evenly the remaining stones will just be put in at once afterwards. Meaning that in round 5 the player has to return 5 stones each and then return the remaining 2 stones afterwards at once. The same for e.g. round 7, first he or she has to return 7 stones and then the remaining 5 stones at once.
The player wins, who manages in his or her turn to do the correct return pattern up to round 12 and does not lose the Olmenye in between.
The winner can then optionally select one of the remaining players and say "Ai shoo enkerai" (I gave you a child) and that selected player can then start trying again. The rotation continues without the winner.


graphic to explain
Every player has a Olmenye (father) stone. The 12 cow stones are in the middle. Only one is playing at a time.

item.title: G3 Olbanto
item.description:
Name: Olbanto
Player size: 3-6
Age: 6-15
Sex: Both
Duration: 2-30
Occasion: leisure
Category: dexterity
Traditional: no
Material needed: each player needs 1 small and round fruit or ball
Mechanics: pick-up and deliver, dexterity, variable player order


Name explanation: Olbanto is Maa and means "something small and round". In English or Swahili the game is called banto (with a soft t)
History: It is more modern and small yellow and round fruits are used (called "Intulele" in Maa and "solanum incanum" as botanical name) or kids in town can buy small and round balls which are sold in shops and called bands or bantos. They are cheap and accessible and can usually be bought for 5 Ksh.
Usage: Played often by kids and the bantos can be bought in shops
Information retrieval:
Ezekiel Roimen interviewed Senewa Maison on the 12-11-2024


Players start at a line which is around 2 meters away from hole.
The goal is to get the balls into that hole. For that the players start after each other to throw/roll the ball towards the hole.
If nobody manages to get into the hole the players start where their ball stopped last time in the order based on how close they were to the hole (the closest one can go first)
The winner is the one who reaches into the hole first.
Often this game is repeated many rounds and the wins of each player are counted.


graphic to explain
Players start at a line to throw their bantos. The winner is the one who reaches the hole first.

item.title: G4 Ntapipiyio
item.description:
Name: Ntapipiyio
Player size: 4+
Age: 5-13
Sex: Both
Duration: 10-20 (depends heavily on player size)
Occasion: leisure
Category: singing, sitting
Traditional: yes
Material needed: -
Mechanics: player elimination, fixed pattern/ pattern building


Name explanation: ? (probably a Maa word)
History: traditionally played with the same passed-on song
Usage: often especially when children sit around and rest
Information retrieval:
Ezekiel Roimen interviewed Neng'arua ole Mukunti on the 13-11-2024


Players sit down in one line with stretched legs forward.
One main player sings the game song and taps each foot after each other with every syllable.
When the song is over the last foot he touched has to be removed (bend).
If one player got removed his or her two legs that player is out, but still sits with both legs bended
The tapping goes back and forth while the song is sung and bended legs are skipped
The song goes as follows:
"Ntapipiyio ntapipiyio aa muntara rinta aa dede dede dede pae,
aarintaa rinta ngurme aa ngurme ngurme tenkeria"
"Tenkeria" means end and is sung and tapped as one
The player who remains last with one or two stretched legs wins:
The game is often repeated multiple times.

item.title: G5 Osuyiet
item.description:
Name: Osuyiet (Bow and Arrows practice)
Player size: 5-20
Age: 20-40
Sex: male
Duration: 3-5 hours
Occasion: exercise
Category: sport
Traditional: yes
Material needed: weapons
Mechanics: dexterity


Name explanation: Osuyiet is a Maa word and refers to the head of the arrow.
History: Traditionally the Maasai would practice a lot with arrow and bow and use it to shoot wild animals or to fight other sections or tribes. Today however, it is of less relevance due to the wild life protection regulations and the fact that tensions are usually managed to be settled by negotiations (often with government help).
Usage: It is still practiced today, but significantly less, and only far away from the settlements like Mile 46. Sometimes young boys also build their own bows and try to practice by themselves.
Information retrieval:
Ezekiel Roimen interviewed Lapiyioi ole Mampurre on the 13-11-2024


Bow and arrow practice where the players try to aim at something from near or far.
The player with the best aim wins.

item.title: G6 Enkeshi
item.description:
Name: Enkeshi
Player size: 2-6
Age: 30+
Sex: male
Duration: 30-90
Occasion: mental competition
Category: board game
Traditional: yes
Material needed: 1 Enkeshi board (with 2 times 8 holes) and 48 stones
Mechanics: pick-up and deliver, deck/bag building, area control, grid/area movement, pattern building


Name explanation: "Enkeshi (pl. Inkeshi)" comes from the Maa word "Enkesha" which means to compete. The stones are called "Inkishu" (meaning cows), possibly the name could also come from that.
History:
This is a very traditional game, which is for men only, but the story goes that a widowed woman introduced this game first to the Maasai men. It is said that the widow still had many cows, but no one to assist her with the cow deliveries of new calves. Because of that she taught this game to men so that they stay at her home. When the cows gave birth she could ask the playing men who were around to assist.
Traditionally this game is only for Maasai men after they underwent their last big ceremony, the "Olngesher". In this ceremony the left and right hand groups are joined together. The left hand group is a bit younger and has to "catch up" to the right hand group. See more here: Description > Maasai age groups While it was thus only allowed for the 5th and last age group to play the game, younger men would sometimes still build and play it in the sand while herding cattle.
The board is traditionally made from a special tree called Olng'osua by proper carving men.
Usage: Nowadays it is played less and less and only some people still know how to play it. But it used to be very famous before. The game has two sides with 1:1 as a default, but it is often played in teams as well (e.g. 2:2 or 3:3).
Information retrieval:
Ezekiel Roimen interviewed Lapiyioi ole Mampurre on the 13-11-2024


The board has 8 holes on each sided and the game is played in two opposing teams.
For the beginning each side puts 4 stones in each of the 6 holes on the right hand and the two left holes are left empty.
One side starts by grabbing all the 4 stones from one hole on their side and continues anti-clockwise by putting the stones from the hand back into the wholes one each until the last stone is from the hand is put
If in that hole there are other stones, all stones from that hole are grapped and the previous step is repeated.
This is continued until a hole with no stones is reached with a last stone from the hand.
The first round of this is especially important as the first end points determine the bank of each side. These two stones in the holes were only one stone remains are called "Olker" (meaning male sheep) and they become the bank of the corresponding side. The bank is called "Emoti" (meaning pot).
Afterwards the players continue in the same manner but now they can start from any hole - expect the bank hole of the other side
The game ends when no movements can be done anymore. This happens when no other hole, besides the two bank holes, has enough stones to reach the next hole.
Now, the stones in the two banks are counted and the side with the most stones wins.
The rules of this game may seem simple, but the dynamics and strategies can quickly become sophisticated.

item.title: G7 Enkukuo
item.description:
Name: Enkukuo
Player size: 4+
Age: 7-14
Sex: both
Duration: 5-15
Occasion: leisure
Category: mental
Traditional: yes
Material needed: a small piece of charcoal
Mechanics: acting, scenario driven


Name explanation: "Enkukuo" is a Maa word and means charcoal, but can also mean voting
History: This game is very traditional and also has a lot engrained Maasai culture in it. For example, the seven stages through which the teams have to go through are also descriptive of what is important in Maasai culture. They are meant to remind people of good development - from a bad state of dirty water to entering a good house with a good environment. See the instructions for the seven stages.
Usage: It is usually played at night at around 9 p.m. until midnight. There is a believe that when played during the day, livestock will be lost. The game can also be used to teach children about the importance of caring about the environment as the seven stages characterise a positive development
Information retrieval:
Ezekiel Roimen interviewed Rimanto Mukunti on the 13-11-2024


The game is played in two teams, which usually give themselves a name of a Maasai clan (one Maasai section has usually many clans) or of one of the five Maasai age group or any other name
The game will be started by the group who prepared the charcoal, as usually the coal has to be fresh from a burning fire place and cooled down by water or saliva
One person from that team will start by pretending to place the small charcoal on the palms of his teammates, who close their hands to fists right after.
After this, the other team has to nominate one person, who has to guess the person who has the charcoal. Even the person who was pretending to give the charcoal still could have it in one of his or her fists.
Normally, it is enough to guess the right person, but sometimes when only few players play this game the correct hand has to be guessed as well.
The tension of this game often makes smaller kids laugh and this can be used as indication, who has the charcoal.
If the location of the charcoal was guessed correctly it is the other's team turn and that team gets one point. If not the same team starts again with "distributing" the charcoal amongst them and they get a point.
The game is played until one team gets seven points. The seventh point is usually referred to as "entering the house"
The 7 point stages of the game are called:
"Enkare neingole ilasho" (the water that is spoiled calves)
"Enkare nasila" (the clean water)
"Nasheta ematua nabo" (the building with one side)
"Nasheta imatuan arre" (the building with two sides)
"Nasheta imatuan uni" (the building with thre sides)
"Emparnat olerai" (the complete permanent house)
"Aajing aji" (entering the house) -> this is the winning stage

item.title: G8 Olenkiserpep
item.description:
Name: Olenkiserpep
Player size: 2-15
Age: 10-25
Sex: male
Duration: 30-60
Occasion: exercise
Category: throwing, dexterity
Traditional: yes
Material needed: 1 stick per player
Mechanics: dexterity, scenario driven


Name explanation: "Olenkiserpep" is a Maa word and describes the sound and action of the sliding sticks.
History:
This game is very traditionally and used as a way of approaching girls, by competing for them and teasing them if one has "won" a particular girl. Traditionally only girls from other clans can be considered for a marriage, but this is ignored for this game as it is only playing with potential relationships. Still, after the game the players often approach the ladies who they won and sometimes relationships start from it.
The sticks to play with are traditionally from a shrub called "Ositeti" (Grewia Bicolor) and have to be very straight. Each young man should have his own stick.
Usage: It is still very much played nowadays by young boys in the same manner.
Information retrieval:
Ezekiel Roimen interviewed Joshua Kimirei Mayiasek on the 14-11-2024


The game should take place on a straight road or field and can be started by any player from the starting line which is previously drawn into the sand.
The players will slide their stick in a straight manner forward, with the goal to slide as far as possible. The stick has to touch the ground at the starting line, otherwise the throw does not count.
For each round the players decide for a name of a girl of similar or younger age which they now. The round is then about this girl.
The player who slided the furthest wins the round and thereby also the girl.
This repeated until the players decided to end it or until one player reaches a previously agreed number of girls.
The player who "won" the most girls, wins.

item.title: G9 Eepa
item.description:
Name: Eepa (Wrestling)
Player size: 2+
Age: 10-35
Sex: male
Duration: 10+
Occasion: exercise
Category: fighting
Traditional: yes
Material needed: -
Mechanics: dexterity


Name explanation: The name "Eepa" is Maa and means trying.
History: This game is traditionally used to determine among the warrior (Morran) age group who is the strongest. It is also a way to impress women and often played by smaller boys as well, who aspire to become like a Morran.
Usage: Traditonally there were also big competitions between different villages and sections, but nowadays it is only played locally (in the Ewuas area).
Information retrieval:
Ezekiel Roimen interviewed Joshua Kimirei Mayiasek on the 14-11-2024


It's a one versus one wrestling game, without weapons on a open and sandy field.
The player wins who manages to put the other one down a certain amount of times (which have to be agreed upon before the game starts)
The player change in a manner that in the end the strongest one is determined.

item.title: G10 Kupepeta
item.description:
Name: Kupepeta
Player size: 2-6
Age: 7-14
Sex: male
Duration: 10+
Occasion: exercise
Category: ball game
Traditional: somewhat
Material needed: 1 ball
Mechanics: dexterity, set collection, point collection


Name explanation: Kupepeta is a Kiswahili word and originally refers to the process of separating grain from chaff by throwing it into the air and letting the wind blow away the lighter chaff.
History: It was already played 40 years ago, but is not a traditional game.
Usage: The game is played by young boys, who often use a self-made ball.
Information retrieval:
Ezekiel Roimen interviewed David Kerore on the 15-11-2024


The first player starts to kick the ball into the air and then bumps the ball repeatedly with the same leg.
Each bounce is counted loudly and the player has to stop when the ball touches the ground.
The number of bounces will then be added to the score of that player and its the next player's turn.
The scores are written and changed into the sand as a table with either numbers or the initials of the players as header and their score below. After each turn the score of that player will be updated accoridingly.
The players decide when to end the game, but then the player with the highest total score wins.

item.title: G11 Ready
item.description:
Name: Ready (before it was called Koipima)
Player size: 2+
Age: 5-13
Sex: both
Duration: 5+
Occasion: exercise
Category: jumping
Traditional: somewhat
Material needed: 1 stone
Mechanics: dexterity, pattern building


Name explanation: Now it is just an English word, but it used to be called "Koipima" (Maa for measured)
History: new game
Usage: encountered on the school yard during breaks
Information retrieval:
encountered by Ezekiel Roimen and Emil Rugenstein when they visited EWuas primary school on the 09-07-2025
also mentioned by David Kerore when Ezekiel Roimen interviewed him on the 15-11-2024


A field of 2 x 5 rectangles is drawn. With the last field on each side being longer than the other ones.
Then one player starts by throwing a stone into the first rectangle on one side.
Now the player has to jump into that tile and kick the stone on one leg only into the next rectangle until he or she reaches the end and then has to come back on the other side. The player has two jump on leg but can rest and put both legs down in the longer rectangles at the end.
During this the stone cannot move further than one rectangle at a time and also the feet of the jumping player are not allowed to touch the lines. If this happens an outside player screams "banned" and the next player can try.
If a player finishes the first round, he or she now has two throw the stone into the second rectangle, jump to that rectangle and then start from there again.
This is then continued until the 5th rectangle and then backwards on the other side.
It rarely happens that a player finishes all stages.

Outline of the game plan.

Name explanation: Mahewa is a Kiswahili word and refers to the air

Usage: It is played by young boys to compete, impress and have fun.
Information retrieval:

The players will prepare a somewhat soft and sandy landing space and then jump from a heightened point like a pile of tubes or a cement back.
The goal to do impressive flips.
If one player fails his jump the others will laugh, but they are also supportive and teach each other.

item.title: G14 Oltingilo
item.description:
Name: Oltingilo (Rounder)
Player size: 5+
Age: 5-14
Sex: both
Duration: 5-15
Occasion: exercise
Category: sport
Traditional: somewhat
Material needed: -
Mechanics: rondels, player elimination, dexterity


Name explanation: Oltingilo is the Maa word for the game and refers to the rounds the player make. In English this game is called rounder.
History: It's a traditional game, that has a traditional song to it that is sung while playing it and originally also involved kids trying to escape from the middle of the circle. However, the game seems to have evolved and it is now played in a simpler version.
Usage: It is still played when many children come together for example in the school break.
Information retrieval:
Ezekiel Roimen interviewed Jane Shapashina on the 20-11-2024


The game is started by all players (e.g. the whole class of students) making a circle by holding hands.
Then everyone runs clockwise as they sing "Oltingilo, oltingilo, ..." or "Rounder, rounder, ..."
The players start running slowly, but then become faster and faster.
When one player falls down, he or she is out and has to leave the circle.
This is continued until only two players remain - they are then the winners.

Age: 5-11
Sex: both

Traditional: no

Name explanation (if applicable): -
History: It has been around for a while but is not a real traditional game
Usage: especially played by the small kids in primary school, but also older kids
Information retrieval:
Ezekiel Roimen interviewed Jane Shapashina on the 20-11-2024


One player has to fill a bottle with sand, while the other two players try to hit that player with a ball from a certain distance and opposing sides.
Only one ball is used and the main player wins if he or she manages to fill the bottle with sand without being hit by the ball from the other two players.
The game is often repeated many times and has an interesting component of time pressure which makes it fun to play.

item.title: NG1 Maasai Village
item.description:
New game that revolves around how people can act together to protect nature.
This game is meant as inspiration and can be tweaked and modified in all ways that the players or the game master can think of - towards a certain teaching purpose or just towards more fun.


Name: Maasai Village (preliminary name)
Player size: 4-8
Duration: decided by game master but around 15min
Traditional: no
Material needed: small stones, something to draw (sand or pen & paper), and a coin or other flipping device


Inspired by traditional arrangement of Maasai settlements and their food sharing practices.
Also includes invasive species dynamic with quadratic growth.
In general this game works well if the game master uses story telling (e.g. narrating how the village wakes up or now has to make a decision in the evening, etc.) and the game master can reinvent, extend and bend the rules in that matter, to keep the game dynamic interesting and filled with learning moments


all players start with one stones which symbolize one cows
their is one game master who moderates the game through the different stages, controls for correct coin flipping, draws the invasive species (into sand or on a paper) and controls the end conditions
in every round

every player who has at least one cow can flip a coin or uproot one plant
when flipping a coin, head means this player gets an additional cow and tails means no new cow is born
when uprooting one plant, the player can delete one

then they have to kill at least one cow from a player which has to put the stone voluntarily into the middle (afterwards the cow is then taken by the game master)
here a lot of discussions are expected and in a way this is the heart of the game
at this stage players can also do other arrangement like renting a cow to other players who don't have any cow

Afterwards a potential drought or disease kills a cow of every player. For this the game master flips a coin twice and only two times tail means that a stone is taken from every player

the invasive species grows
growing stages of invasive species
1 stroke, 2 strokes, 3 strokes = 1 plant (grass plant painted with 3 stalks)
afterwards the plants double at every stage
end of game if
either all players lose the game by
a) the invasive species reaches 16 or more plants
or b) no cow is killed or can be killed in a round
or the game master decides that the time is over
the game master has the freedom to decide freely as this will promote more interesting collaboration strategies
rational game theory but also common sense explain that the players will act very differently if they e.g. know that the game will be over in three rounds. That's why a more realistic situation is created if the game master decides more freely when the game is ended
afterwards the cows of each player are then counted and the one with the most cows wins
but also the whole community can "win" in a game if they managed to have many cows altogether (compared to another game round)
maybe play around and experiment what winning condition works better (most total cows as whole group or most individual cows from one player)

item.title: NG2 Maji Safi au Mchanga Chafu
item.description:
New game that revolves around how people can act together to protect nature.
This game is meant as inspiration and can be tweaked and modified in all ways that the players or the game master can think of - towards a certain teaching purpose or just towards more fun.


Name: Maji Safi au Mchanga Chafu
Player size: 3 - 8
Duration:
Traditional: no
Material needed: sand, plate, cups


Name explanation: Maji Safi au Mchanga Chafu is Swahili and means "clear water or dirty sand"
The dynamic of common pollution (sand stacking up), which requires action that has a certain sacrifice (giving away from one's own water reserve), can be used to explore collective action problems and solutions together


everyone has a cup and gets a bit of water every round from the game master
the game ends and one player wins if he has a full cup (potentially it is possible that all win together in a round)
but there is a metal plate on which the game master puts sand every round (a varying amount)
everyone loses if after the sand is put (always in the centre) the whole area is covered
that's why after the sand is put in every round players have to discuss if some of them use some of the water to clean sand from the plate

item.title: General Games
item.description:
This is work-in-progress collection of games that are played by the Maasai community in Elangata Wuas in Kenya.

This is only a collection of some games. However, the list is based on walking around Elangata Wuas and asking people of different ages, what their favourite games are.

G1 Chango Lo Che
G2 Osurruo
G3 Olbanto
G4 Ntapipiyio
G5 Osuyiet
G6 Enkeshi
G7 Enkukuo
G8 Olenkiserpep
G9 Eepa
G10 Kupepeta
G11 Ready
G12 Mahewa
G13 Draft
G14 Oltingilo

Note: The "mechanics" field of the game descriptions is meant to provoke thoughts about different mechanics that are commonly used in this context with the intention to serve as inspiration for the kind of games that could be designed together with e.g. teachers. The field and its intentions are based on the Game of Games which was designed by Caroline Archambault.


With certain clapping patterns:
Police Central: Children in circle and "pass on" a clap by receiving on the right and passing on with the left hand. At the end of a singing song that kid can shoot one of the other kids from the circle. Than this is repeated again without that kid.
Played at Emirishoi Primary School when visited by Ezekiel Roimen and Emil Rugenstein on 17-07-2025.
Video: Game-PoliceCentral.mp4
Sumsum: Another clapping game whereby 4 kids, standing in a rectangle, clap in a certain pattern with both hands. Sometimes across each other, sometimes changing to the left or right partner. The song continues into the ABC and the game is started again when one of the kids misses the correct pattern.
Played at Emirishoi Primary School when visited by Ezekiel Roimen and Emil Rugenstein on 17-07-2025
Video: Game-Sumsum.mp4
Colour jumping game: Kids play outside and draw three or more long fields into the sand in which they line up. Every line has one colour and one kid now screams one colour after another and the other kids have to jump to that line/column. The catch is that the kid can scream non-existing colours . If kids move at a call of a colour that is not included or if they jump to the wrong column they have to step to the side. The game continues till only one kid is left.
Witnessed by Emil Rugenstein while walking around in Elangata Wuas Town
Video: Game-ColourJumping.mp4

The goal is to develop new games which make people think about how people can protect nature by acting together. The process itself of designing such games can be a way to spark thoughts and ideas on this topic. Playing and designing these games can also be used to observe how people think and act collectively.

Emil Rugenstein designed two games which can serve as an example of the kind of games that can be useful for game-based learning and research about Collective Action and Nature Protection

item.title: Workshop (Collective Action and Nature Protection)
item.description:
Topic: How to act together to protect nature?
Method: Develop, brainstorm or/and play games which revolve around that question.
Caroline Archambault proposed a plan A, B, and C strategy
plan A: "develop games together"
inspired by the Game of Games approach, form small groups which have to creatively develop their own games around the given topic and with possibly some given constraints on "mandatory" game mechanics, game utensils, and setting
plan B: "hacking games they already know"
take games they already now and think about how you could convert them into something where people learn about X
plan C: "what do you think about these ideas and games?"
ask them what they already know about biodiversity loss /collective action and try game which we developed before



Introduce myself and ask some general questions about the class to warm up
Split class into groups of around 4 and hand out paper
possibly consult a teacher for good group splits


Give the groups time to write down answers on the following questions
On Collective Action:
Where do people act together?
How can people act together?
When do people fail to act together?
On Nature Protection
Why is a healthy nature important to humans? (Potentially only verbally together to save time)
What problems does our nature have right now? (Potentially only verbally as well)
How can we protect nature?


Collect some answers, but this should not be exhaustive
good way to do this is in a lightning format -> every group says after each other one answer that has not been said before


Collect games they know and like and make them think about them
Ask to answer the following questions:
What games do you like? Why?
But ask them to go beyond big ball sports i.e. football, volleyball, netball and handball
What do players learn in these games?


Again collect some answers
Now, ask them to design a game in which the players learn something about how we can protect nature by acting together by either
a) coming up with new games
or b) modifying the collected games
Provide some inspiration by
providing list with materials, which they can but don't have to use:
small stones
sand
timer/clock
cups
dice
ball
pen and paper
string
anything else they can think of
prompting them that students like them should like to play it
reminding them to think back to the answers of the previous two sections


Go around and help brainstorming
It's ok and expectable that they will be probably be a bit confused for the first 5 - 10 mins
But if all goes good, then here the magic happens
If not jump to Option C


Explain game and play it first with one group while others are watching (10min)
NG1 Maasai Village
Then let them play together in groups (10-15min)
possibly merge groups so the groups are better oversee-able
encourage them to play multiple times


Option A&B:
Share different games and let the groups explain it
Encourage a concise explanation as this otherwise can easily crash the time frame
Option C:
Ask them to reflect on the game play and what different strategies where used and to which results they led
